hedline.hl1: Selling African Art Over the Internet

abstract.p: Marketing executive Rita Roberts Hill and husband, graphic designer Lee Hill, sell African art through Internet Web site during evenings and on weekends; photo (S)

block.p: The myth of easy e-commerce money has been all but dispelled by now -- even Web giants like Amazon.com are still struggling to turn a profit -- but Rita Roberts Hill and her husband Lee Hill have found a way to make the Web work for them: they didn't quit their day jobs.

On weekdays, Mrs. Hill works as a marketing executive for a Time Warner subsidiary and Mr. Hill works as a graphic designer. In the evening and on weekends, however, they work together on Fine African Art (www.fineafricanart.net), an online gallery of Mrs. Hill's collection of traditional African art.

The myth of easy e-commerce money has been all but dispelled by now -- even Web giants like Amazon.com are still struggling to turn a profit -- but Rita Roberts Hill and her husband Lee Hill have found a way to make the Web work for them: they didn't quit their day jobs.

On weekdays, Mrs. Hill works as a marketing executive for a Time Warner subsidiary and Mr. Hill works as a graphic designer. In the evening and on weekends, however, they work together on Fine African Art (www.fineafricanart.net), an online gallery of Mrs. Hill's collection of traditional African art.

From a home office/gallery in Mount Vernon, the couple use their respective expertise to run the company. Ms. Hill, who studied art in Ghana and has been a collector for more than 15 years, researches and buys art from importers. Mr. Hill designed, programmed and maintains the Web site.

Because they have no employees, their business has virtually no overhead. So when they sell, for instance, a wooden Pongue Mask from the Congo ($125), the profit is all their's. That's a business model Amazon could learn from.
